WIDENING OF THOMSON ROAD


    3. Mr Sia Khoon Seong asked the Minister for National Development and Communications when the stretch of Thomson Road between its junctions with Balestier Road and Moulmein Road will be widened and whether the plans to widen the road include (i) provision of a pedestrian crossing with controlled lighting; (ii) provision of a special lane at the Thomson Road/Balestier Road junction to allow cars to turn right from Thomson Road into Balestier Road at all times and not just between 7 p.m. and 7 a.m. as at present; and (iii) special provision to allow cars of residents in Novena Estate to turn right from Jalan Novena into Thomson Road and to turn right from Thomson Road into Jalan Novena more easily and safely than at present.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, works to widen the stretch of Thomson Road (between Balestier Road and Moulmein Road) are expected to commence in July 1977.

    No pedestrian crossing with controlled lighting will be provided. This is because there are already too many traffic signals along this stretch of Thomson Road, Instead, a pedestrian overhead bridge will be constructed in front of the Novena Church in conjunction with the road widening scheme to ease traffic flow and for the safety of the pedestrians.

    Cars will be allowed to turn right from Thomson Road into Balestier Road at all times after the road has been widened.

    An extra lane will be provided for right-turning vehicles from Thomson Road to Jalan Novena Barat. However, for traffic and safety reasons, right-turning will be prohibited from Jalan Novena Barat to Thomson Road.

ADDITIONAL BUS SERVICE TO BEDOK NEW TOWN
(NEIGHBOURHOOD I)


    4. Haji Sha'ari Bin Tadin asked the Minister for National Development and Communications if he will consider asking the Singapore Bus Service to provide additional bus services to Bedok New Town (Neighbourhood I) as the present services are inadequate.

    The Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, Bedok New Town is presently served throughout the day by three SBS services. They are Service 3 to Geylang and Chinatown, Service 12 to East Coast Road and beyond, and Service 220 which runs along the industrial area in Bedok Plain to the nearby Chai Chee Terminal. At Chai Chee Terminal, there are 15 other services operating to major destination areas. During peak periods, there are two additional Blue Arrow Services, i.e. Service 302 to Shenton Way and Service 307 to Orchard Road. More buses have been added on to these services during the last few months as the number of residents in the area increases.

    The long-term plan is for all new towns, including Bedok New Town, to be served by a system of internal and external bus services. Within each town, a comprehensive network of internal services will bring residents from the various neighbourhoods to the town centre terminal where external services to the Central Business District, major industrial zones, and other towns will originate. Where demand is high, express services will be introduced. Such a system will make best use of the limited resources and restricted road space and reduce operating costs. The alternative of linking each part of the town directly with various destinations is an expensive way of providing good service.

Column: 381



    Service 220, which was introduced on the 1 5th March last year and is now enjoying good patronage, is the forerunner of internal services for Bedok New Town. It will be strengthened with additional buses as and when necessary. More internal services will be introduced to serve other neighbourhoods as they become occupied.

    The SBS is working closely with the HDB on the design of the Bedok Town Centre Terminal for the safe and convenient transfer by commuters between internal and external services. The terminal is expected to be completed in 18 months' time.

    Pending the introduction of the new bus system and completion of the Town Centre Terminal, the SBS will look into the possibility of extending more of its services to Neighbourhood I of the Bedok New Town as an interim measure.

RESERVED SITE IN FRONT OF BLOCK 30, MARINE PARADE


    5. Mr Goh Chok Tong asked the Minister for Law and the Environment whether the site reserved for the construction of schools in front of Block 30, Marine Parade, which is fast becoming an obnoxious wasteland, could be levelled for use as a temporary football or open field if the construction of schools is not scheduled to commence within a year.

    The Minister for Law and the Environment (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the planned construction of schools on this reclaimed site is not expected to commence within a year. Action is in hand to convert the site into a temporary playground for children in the neighbourhood. Earthworks and tree planting are expected to commence in about three months' time as soon as tenders are called for and funds are available. This will ensure that the site does not become waste land.

Column: 382



    Meanwhile, the Parks and Recreation Department will ensure that the vegetation is under control and the Ministry of the Environment will continue to occasionally spray oil on the site to prevent mosquito breeding.

    Mr Ahmad Haleem (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister for Law and the Environment tell me if the same facility can be extended to other school sites in Singapore?

    Mr Barker: That depends on the other school sites. Sir. Without proper investigation, I am afraid I would not be able to give a concrete answer to the Member for Telok Blangah. In this particular case, however, there had been negotiations between the Ministry of Education and other offices to decide whether or not to proceed with the construction of schools. Meanwhile, as the hon. Member for Marine Parade has suggested, it is a good idea to turn the site into a playground. On the facts of this case, we can assist. But whether or not we can assist in other cases depends on the circumstances. However we try to be of assistance, wherever possible.

APPLICATIONS FOR CITIZENSHIP
(Particulars)


    6. Mr Goh Chok Tong asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education how many applications for Singapore citizenship were under consideration as at 1st February, 1977, outstanding for more than three years, and whether steps are being taken to expedite the processing of those applications.

    The Minister for Home Affairs and Education (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of applications for Singapore citizenship under consideration as

Column: 383

as 1st February, 1977 was 25,110. Of this number, some 15,000 or 60% have been outstanding for three years or more. However, some 6,800 of these outstanding applications are, in fact, repeat applications from persons who have applied again after their previous applications had been rejected. Nonetheless, they add to the backlog.

    The number of applications received and the number of applications dealt with during the last three years are as follows: 

       Applications    Applications

Year     Received       Dealt With        Difference



1974      7,897           4,248             3,649

1975      7,144           8,400             1,256

1976      7,706          11,552             3,846


    These figures show that in 1974 there was an addition to the backlog of 3,649 applications. However, in 1975 there was a net reduction of the backlog by 1,256 applications. Last year the backlog was reduced by a further 3,846 applications.

    Since March 1975 a committee has been meeting weekly to assess applications before submitting them to me for a decision. This has speeded up the process. In addition, my officials are currently reviewing the powers of the Registrar of Citizens with the view to delegating to him more powers to approve applications which are straight-forward and satisfy clearly laid down criteria. However, I must explain that there is a limit to which the processing can be speeded up. This is because many of those whose applications have been rejected re-apply almost immediately. This means that the faster they are rejected the faster they rejoin the so-called backlog.

SCHOOL TEXTBOOKS


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education whether he is aware that pupils in some schools were unable to get certain textbooks from their school bookshops or other bookshops and what steps his Ministry will take to ensure that textbooks are readily available either at

Column: 384

the school bookshops or other bookstores to avoid unnecessary inconvenience to parents of having to hunt for books.

    The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Chai Chong Yii) (for the Minister for Home Affairs and Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, we are aware that at the beginning of this school year, some pupils of a few schools had problems in obtaining certain textbooks. This was due mainly to uneven distribution made by publishing firms. The problems were resolved within two weeks.

    The following steps are being taken to prevent its recurrence:

    1. Principals will be asked to prescribe the textbooks required in June of each year.

    2. Relevant publishers will be notified by August, so that sufficient copies could be printed and made available.

    3. At the end of the school year, pupils will be issued with booklists. The booklists will include the addresses and telephone numbers of the publishers.

    4. Arrangement has been made for all publishers to hold reserve stocks of textbooks.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, I understand that a piece of State land bounded by Surin and

Column: 385

Aroozoo Avenues is earmarked for a community centre and a swimming pool.

    As for the provision of funds to build a swimming pool there, I recall that the Member for Punggol raised a similar question in 1973. I must answer his question in the same manner. Funds for the construction of the swimming pool must come from the approved yearly Budget allocation to the Singapore Sports Council (SSC), or from donations and contributions. The swimming pool must, therefore, vie for priority within the Budget allocation with all other projects under the SSC Master Plan for the development of sports facilities. I believe that the SSC Master Plan for 1976-1982 provided originally for three swimming pools in the North Zone, two of which are to be sited in the Surin Avenue area. However. I believe also that the Singapore Sports Council has decided to defer the construction of swimming pools in that area until after the Ang Mo Kio Swimming Complex is completed in 1979 when the position will be reviewed.

    If the Member for Punggol is impatient for the development of a swimming pool in the area, perhaps he may wish to start a Fund for this purpose. The Government will help by giving tax exemption to donations to the Fund.

    The Minister for Culture and Science and Technology (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the percentage of educational-informational programme is very high. In fact, it is the highest among the highest in this region. Of the programmes produced locally, nearly 58% are in the educational-informational category. These include news, documentaries, forums and magazine

Column: 387

programmes. Only 17% of our local productions are musical-variety shows.

    Sir, far from cancelling out the work of the Ministry of Education, our TV service does lend support to the efforts of the Education Ministry in promoting, for example, music appreciation and cultural activity amongst our young people. The music and dance presentations included in its Youth Festivals have always been recorded and telecast. We have currently, a monthly Students' Concert which features items contributed by schools. Music appreciation programmes such as "Great Composers". "Who's afraid of Opera" and "Classical masterpieces" have also been, and will continue to be, telecast.

    We need not be worried that TV commercials will have undue influence on viewers as the Member for Potong Pasir has feared. All advertisements are carefully scrutinised before they are accepted for telecast. They are accepted for telecast if they do not contravene the provisions of the Station's Programme and Copy Codes. These provisions are more stringent than those of other media. There have been advertisements which have not been accepted for telecast although they have been passed for exhibition in the cinemas and publication in the press. Last year, a total of 199 advertisements were rejected for showing on TV. They included advertisements which made unwarranted or superlative claims, featured unkempt longhaired males or females indecently clad.

    Acceptance of advertisements for telecast does not mean the Station's or the Government's full endorsement of the manner of presentation or of the product advertised. For example, acceptance of commercials promoting jeans does not mean Government endorsement or otherwise of that apparel. We are only concerned with selling air-time. So long as the product being advertised is not objectionable and is presented in good taste, we see no reason why it should be rejected. There are, of course, many gullible consumers who can be

Column: 388

hooked on anything with or without advertisement. They can only be educated either by CASE, by the documentaries and talks on TV, or by their own mistakes.

    The earning of revenue from the selling of air-time for advertisements is not the dominant pre-occupation of RTS. If revenue was the prime factor, we would have allowed - as is done elsewhere advertisements to be associated with our news and advertisements in informational and educational programmes. But this is not the case.

    The Member for Sembawang complained that too many imported programmes are being telecast and that 80% of the artistes in the musical variety shows come from abroad The truth is that imported programmes are cheaper to acquire and are more popular, more exciting and entertaining. Besides, we do not have the capacity to produce all the programmes locally. It is not true to say that 80% of the artistes are from overseas, He may have an eye for the Taiwan singers, but if he sees beyond them he will find that they comprise no more than a third of all the performers.

    A greater output of local dramas or serials hinges upon the availability of scriptwriters and performers. Apart from writing for TV and Radio, there are insufficient opportunities and scope to induce more people to take up scriptwriting and performance on a full-time basis. A related consideration is the need for a greater number of staff such as set designers, carpenters, staging crew and wardrobe personnel.

    I am happy to note that the Member for Whampoa finds the branch libraries useful, and indeed they are. We will continue to build these branch libraries in new housing estates and areas where the size of the population justifies the building of such branch libraries. There are already two branch libraries in Queenstown and Toa Payoh. The next branch library will be opened in Katong in 1978. Plans are also being prepared for new branch libraries at Telok

    Coming to the Ministry of Science and Technology, the Member for Geylang East has touched on the matter of solar energy. The Ministry has been keeping under constant study and review developments in the use of alternative energy sources besides fuel oil. Research into these areas is being encouraged. Studies on the use of solar energy have been undertaken by the Mechanical and Engineering Department of the University of Singapore and research is still in progress. There has been some progress in the development of methods for the conversion of solar energy into electrical energy by solar engines in countries like Israel, Italy and the USA. Although the technical feasibility of such methods to produce electrical energy on a small scale has been demonstrated, such methods have not yet reached the stage of being economically viable. Further, the amount of electricity generated by known methods would not be sufficient to meet the needs of blocks of HDB flats. Unless there is a technical breakthrough resulting in drastic cost reduction, it is unlikely that any scheme for the supply of electricity through the use of solar energy would be available in the near future. The Ministry will continue to monitor developments in this field and encourage research in the conversion and utilisation of solar energy.

    The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Chai Chong Yii): Mr Speaker, Sir, several Members have commented on the activities and plans of the Ministry of Education. I shall try to answer those policies and actions which appear to be misunderstood. I shall also outline the decision-making and consultative processes in the Ministry of Education to show that despite contrary views expressed by some Members the Ministry does not rush into changes and ad hoc policies.

Moral and Social Values and Attitudes

    The question has been asked as to what is meant by "Asian values". This term is only a convenient way of referring to the variety of norms, practices and beliefs inherent in the cultures, traditions and customs of Asia. It is intended only in this geographical sense. Since the vast majority of our population are of Chinese, Malay and Indian ethnic origin and we are in a geographically Asian context, it is essential to our survival as a nation that values and attitudes based on the Chinese. Malay and Indian cultures, traditions and customs are promoted and encouraged But this does not mean that Western values and attitudes have no place in our society and school curriculum. It is only the values and attitudes of the West that are pernicious to our society that we are against.

    As for the teaching of these desirable values and attitudes in our schools, while this is done through the subject Education for Living at the primary level, at the secondary level, there is no such single subject but three

Column: 391

separate subjects of Civics, Geography and History. However, the teaching and acquisition of desirable values and attitudes is not by formal lessons in the classroom alone but also by precept and example. Not only teachers but parents, family and friends all have a part to play in this,

Language Policy

    Criticism has been directed at the announcement made by the Ministry of Education on 22nd January regarding first and second language requirements for admission to Junior Colleges and Pre-University classes from 1979. This is no new and ad hoc policy but a continuation and development of the bilingual policy advocated 17 years ago in 1959. It is important for those graduating from universities who will be holding key positions of leadership in our society to be effectively bilingual in their mother tongue and English. The language requirements announced on 22nd January are principally for the purpose of raising the level of the first language of those entering the universities. Employers in both the public and private sectors have complained of the declining standards in language of our university graduates. The universities, on the other hand, blame this on the standard of the students coming to them from the schools.

    The need to raise the level of the first language is shown by the results in English as a first language in the GCE `O' level examinations. In 1973, 35% of those who sat for the examination passed in English as the first language. 37% in 1974 and 44% in 1975. While the intention of the announcement is to raise the level of the first language, we have to ensure that this is not done at the expense of the second language. Therefore, minimum standards have also been specified for the second language for admission to Junior Colleges and Pre-University classes from 1979. But these minimum standards are not high Grade 8 which has been specified for 1979 is really just below pass level, while Grade 7 which

Column: 392

has been specified for 1980 and 1981 is still not even a pass at `O' level, that is, equivalent to a pass at Sec. II or Ill level. These grades should be attainable by most pupils as is shown by the fact that the proportion of pupils who sat for and passed the GCE `O' levels in Chinese as a second language, for example, was 60% in 1973, 57% in 1974, 59% in 1975 and 69% in 1976.

    Nevertheless, the language requirements are not intended as a bar to those who are well qualified for and able to benefit fully from a university training. Consideration may be given to exceptional cases depending on the merits of each. A general exception to those who score not more than an aggregate of 15 points has already been announced. They will be allowed provisional admission to Junior Colleges and Pre-University classes even if they fail to meet the language requirements.

Kindergartens

    A request was made that the Ministry of Education takes over all kindergartens in order to control standard and quality. I wish to inform the House that there is provision for kindergartens to be registered with the Ministry and satisfy certain conditions. Standard and quality of teaching are some of the conditions. I would also like to inform hon. Members that a committee has been set up comprising representatives of the Ministry of Social Affairs, the People's Association and officials of my Ministry to look into the improvements that can be made in kindergarten education.

Village Schools

    It is true that most rural aided schools are small but not all of them are sub-standard. It is my Ministry's policy to encourage the Management Committees of these aided schools to rebuild where there is a need. My Ministry is offering them capital aid up to 50% of the total approved capital expenditure. A number of village schools have already been rebuilt or extended through this scheme.
